newsitem.title: FRANCE: Fischler says higher farm aid acceptable to WTO.
newsitem.headline: Fischler says higher farm aid acceptable to WTO.

text.p: EU Farm Commissioner Franz Fischler said on Wednesday that proposals to increase compensation payments to cereals, beef and dairy farmers could be defended in the next round of world farm trade talks.

The U.S., which has completely decoupled subsidies from production, is expected to lead an attack in World Trade Organisation negotiations starting in 1999 on reducing trade distorting farm subsidies.

As part of reforms aimed at making farmers more competitive on world markets as the EU enlarges eastwards, Fischler has proposed higher payments to farmers to compensate for income losses for intervention price cuts of between 10 and 30 percent.
"It won't make life easy in the WTO but we are going to defend it," Fischler told a news conference.
"It's important we see that the measures are in the 'blue box' and within our obligations to the WTO," he added.
Fischler noted that the EU farmers' organisation COPA had already strongly attacked the proposed payment increase because it would only partially cover expected income losses.
"COPA says we are bowing towards the U.S. and its wishes," he said.
But Fischler added, "The U.S. won't like our intention to increase (farm) exports."

By reducing support prices to competitive levels, the EU hopes to export more grain and other farm products without the routine use of subsidies and thus avoid curbs imposed under the GATT Uruguay Round Agreement.
Fischler said that the reforms would bring savings of 3.7 billion ecus, including 1.4 billion for cereals, in market intervention and export refunds by 2006.
Although higher compensation payments would add 7.7 billion ecus, including 4.1 billion for beef producers, farm spending would remain well an increasing farm spending ceiling, he said.
In a bid to pacify hostile farmers, Fischler stressed, "One of the political objectives of the package is that our farmers and farming families should share the prosperity enjoyed by other sectors."
"One can't simply reduce prices and suggest that farmers should compete," he said, adding that the farmers' role in protecting the environment and keeping rural areas alive should be rewarded.
